discourse_list.title: [Signal Request] SourceCred, stop paying people who are already paid by MakerDAO

content.content: The original justification for SourceCred:    Maker SourceCred Trial   SourceCred believes it can incentivize governance work by providing an effective, decentralized and incentive-compatible way to value contributions.   However, SourceCred payouts have continued even as contributors have secured positions as Core Unit paid employees or Recognized Delegates. The amount of money flowing to new contributors is reduced. For example, @PaperImperium was initially attracted to the forums (from Reddit) due to SourceCred. Given that @PaperImperium now works for @GFXlabs as a paid Recognized Delegate, SourceCred compensation is no longer a major factor in his motivation. @rune also feels that SourceCred is wasted when paid to people who are already paid by MakerDAO. Pros:  Contributors receiving SourceCred will receive larger payouts Hopefully, Maker will attract more contributors because of large payouts  Cons:  Those people who receive income from both SourceCred and as formal MakerDAO contributors will receive less moolah Some MakerDAO-affiliated people may contribute less to the forum     Stop paying people with SourceCred who are already being paid by MakerDAO  Yes No Abstain     0 voters     This Signal Request will remain open for two weeks and close on 2022-02-15T08:00:00Z. If approved then the same question will be posed in an on-chain poll.

psychonaut:  This Signal Request will remain open for two weeks. If approved then the same question will be posed in an on-chain poll   Could you add the date explicitly please      psychonaut:  However, SourceCred payouts have continued even as contributors have secured positions as Core Unit paid employees or Recognized Delegates.   It might be worthwhile separating these. It may make more sense to have delegates still able to access SourceCred, while preventing Core Unit Facilitators and Contributors.
LongForWisdom:  have delegates still able to access SourceCred   Maybe we need a threshold like people paid more than 1000 DAI per month become ineligible?

Thanks for bringing this up! At present, are facilitators already excluded from SourceCred? Unfortunately, excluding all paid contributors may be difficult to execute. For one thing, a master list of anyone receiving regular compensation from the Maker protocol would need to be maintained and updated at least weekly. Maker currently has 100+ paid contributors, so the simple maintenance of this list is extra overhead for @GovAlpha-Core-Unit. Even the exclusion of specific posts like scheduled weekly updates may be an extra burden to put on the GovAlpha staff to track and remove from the SourceCred algorithm. Given human labor costs and the relatively low expense of SourceCred, that may eat up quite a bit of any possible savings. Add in the whack-a-mole game of anon accounts created to preserve what (to an individual) might be a material amount of earnings, and it just seems like a lot of work without sufficient benefit. There is also the simple fact that seeing whose Cred score would have prompted payment, but was zeroed out, will make public via payments flows on the easily accessible SourceCred site who on the forums is a paid contributor, even if their role is rank-and-file. That might or might not pose additional privacy concerns for individuals in a variety of jurisdictions and personal situations. I believe there’s a reason why the GovComms list of DAO actors is being handled in a GDPR compliant way. If the goal is to increase the amount available to attract new members of the DAO, the clearest path would be to increase the size of the SourceCred pool or have a second instance that has payments only for contributors with less than X months’ time on the forum.

GFXlabs:  Unfortunately, excluding all paid contributors may be difficult to execute. For one thing, a master list of anyone receiving regular compensation from the Maker protocol would need to be maintained and updated at least weekly. Maker currently has 100+ paid contributors, so the simple maintenance of this list is extra overhead for @GovAlpha-Core-Unit.   Gov Comms helps to maintain a list.
As a reference, here is the list of benefits for January  image905×1205 69.1 KB
Gah, where is the  button? This is such a waste of money.

FWIW, I just DM-ed the admin to remove my account from the Sourcecred distro, if possible. I do agree that getting new contributors DAI is more important than extra DAI for F3LC (which already has delegate compensation– for now). However, there is a possibility to revisit how we apply sourcecred:     GFXlabs:  second instance that has payments only for contributors with less than X months’ time on the forum.   More curious than anything, could we have a second instance? It would be nice to leverage sourcecred to track contributions but apply the grain and cred in more novel ways. Assuming we have the manpower of course.

Abstaining from this Signal Request as I in general think that’s a fair question to ask, but I have very personal view on it: To give some food for thoughts from someone who heavily benefited from sourcecred (and now from recognized delegate compensation). I am not considering quitting my offchain job for 12k/month, additional 1k-2k/month more is not going to make a huge difference on my decision (this month related to the Signal Requests (here, here) I initiated last week after Flappy Friday. The baseline is usually just coming from the summaries of the MOMC-meetings (we had two this month - here, here) Moving to some kind of company structure for following my passion (surprise: that’s MakerDAO and all of the people related to it!) full-time is absolutely not an option as I want to stay independent here. We all need to decide together how we want to spend our profits, so far I’d say we have been pretty generous with CU-compensation and vesting and what not. At least for me personally this SR confirms my doubts that my work is valuable enough for the DAO to go all-in.  Edit (thanks @psychonaut for reaching out and asking questions): Looks this was a very german way of saying: Compensation for Recognized Delegates is not enough to go all-in (and solo!) right now, so removing source-cred does hurt (my feelings)  This is a different discussion, and should probably not be mixed into this.

ultraschuppi:  additional 1k-2k/month more is not going to make a huge difference on my decision   Hm hm, given that Recognized Delegates are taking a lot of money from SourceCred (as they should as good forum communicators), I propose that we raise the maximum delegate compensation by 3k per month if we kick them off of SourceCred.

Abstaining because I don’t believe you should  take-away  SourceCred away from Part-time CU team members and Delegates that have a small amount of MKR delegated to their platform. Your Poll is not defined well enough–seems rushed. Governance Mining is Real. What are some of the other resolutions the Maker Community can make to expand beyond where Gov participation is today? I think that’s a better question. Also, 3F Delegate is looking to hire College Interns–can I transfer my GRAIN to a new community member that onboards via 3F? @LongForWisdom  It would be a good way to incentivize such individuals via the Cred that 3F Delegate has built over the years. LMK what you think. BTW @psychonaut you should listen to this Pod on solving the trend that “DAO’s are cheapskates” when it comes to Governance Mining but lovers of incentivizing Degenerates

Honest question - how do you even opt out once you’re in? I can’t seem to find any resources on this. Who do I contact? Also, I’m not familiar with how cred accumulates or how payout amounts are calculated, so maybe this is already the case, but it might make sense to introduce some kind of hard cap or diminishing returns on cred each month, while also expanding the funding to even the distributions for newcomers. However, that can probably also be gamed

Difficult question. On the one hand, I think that the comments they write about their work are part of their work, and they get paid for it as a paid contributor.  On the other hand, as they are knowledgeable people, their general comments are a valuable contribution to the daily life of the community. I voted “Yes” because I believe that we should use Sourcecred on an all-or-nothing basis, deciding whether we pay based on performance as measured by Sourcecred or on a contributor contract.  Just a reminder: "The goal of SourceCred is to use this technology to make rewarding labor as nuanced as human contribution often is. " If we rethink the current system, we can pay both SourceCred and contracted contributors as the situation requires. This should pay off for both the DAO and the contributors, so perhaps it is time to rethink the budget.
lollike:  Who do I contact?   Maybe he/she can help you: @sourcecred-trial-adm

Hey, does your question include all people paid by Maker (aside from SourceCred)? What if there is a part-time contributor but only gets paid for about 1-2 hours of work per week? I didn’t submit my answer just yet but I believe that contributors who work less than several hours a week for a CU should be viable to opt-in for SourceCred especially if they bring value that is outside of the scope of what that CU works on.

I’m closing the poll because I want to start fresh with some changes:  Part-time contributors should continue to be included in SourceCred. I think we need a threshold, maybe 5000 DAI per month or less can stay. Those receiving more than that become ineligible. Recognized Delegates shouldn’t lose compensation because of this change. To keep it revenue neutral for them, we can increase the maximum delegate compensation by 3000 DAI per month. Delegates receiving less than 5000 DAI per month (delegates with small MKR weight) can still remain in SourceCred due to previous point.  I think this addresses all the comments. Anybody else have thoughts to add?

Can we table this signal / issue for like 2 weeks? The TL;DR is that GovAlpha has been more or less running SourceCred in maintenance mode for the last 6 months because we haven’t had the time to pay more active attention to it. In the next two weeks we need to focus on determining GovAlpha’s plans and putting together our DAI and MKR budgets for the next 12 months. We do have some analysis work on SourceCred on-going which would provide some input into the issue, but it hasn’t been published yet. Basically, I think we’re likely to end up with better outcomes if you can give us until the 18th to:  Finalize and publish the analysis we’ve done on SourceCred. Put together some options and recommendations for moving forward with incentives / governance mining.
Have marked this as withdrawn based on @psychonaut’s (and my) comments.

I just want to record an alternate solution. I think we could get roughly the same effect as my post two messages above if there were two instances of SourceCred, the current one (unchanged) and another one that was eligible only for people that were not already paid by Maker. People could receive the combined compensation from both SourceCred instances.

ultraschuppi:  Compensation for Recognized Delegates is not enough to go all-in (and solo!) right now,   The issue is that being a recognized delegate was never meant to be a 40-hours-per-week full-time job and indeed, many of the delegates, including yourself, hold an unrelated full-time position. I disagree that the solution is to further increase delegate compensation unless you also require delegates to do a lot more than the things listed here. In this sense, I think delegate compensation, like CU compensation, is currently quite generous even without SourceCred. It has always been the case that some delegates do work that goes above and beyond their role as a delegate. For example, your work with MOMC, starting various signal requests, etc. has nothing to do with being a delegate and should therefore be compensated independently on top of whatever delegate compensation model we have.

AstronautThis:  It has always been the case that some delegates do work that goes above and beyond their role as a delegate. For example, your work with MOMC, starting various signal requests, etc. has nothing to do with being a delegate and should therefore be compensated independently on top of whatever delegate compensation model we have.   That’s right, but stuff beyond being a delegate (like working in MOMC) are currently de-facto compensated with sourcecred

ultraschuppi:  That’s right, but stuff beyond being a delegate (like working in MOMC) are currently de-facto compensated with sourcecred    That’s a fair point and if such work is excluded from SourceCred in the future, then you should indeed be paid for it some other way. My only point above is that an increase in delegate compensation amounts would miss this distinction between people’s contributions as a delegate vs that as a community contributor.

AstronautThis:  That’s a fair point and if such work is excluded from SourceCred in the future, then you should indeed be paid for it some other way.   with the risk of totally derailing the discussion: I was thinking about this for some time already, and I tend to disagree here a bit. Sure, you can be a delegate by just  Create and maintain a public profile. Show up for a ‘Meet your delegate meeting’ Vote on polls and executive proposals. Communicate the reasoning for voting for those polls and executive proposals.  But I don’t think this is enough. I don’t think you are able to make good decisions without being involved in at least some of the areas relevant - not necessarily to provide value but at least to stay in the loop, e.g.:  RWA - onboarding (totally not my domain, so I am usually relying a lot on the opinions of other delegates here) inner workings of the DAO (e.g. @PaperImperium initiative to provide a better structure for Facilitator Offboarding) Risk Parameters and the trade-offs with DAI-growth (the reason I joined MOMC) having a closer look on how markets evolve and what competition is doing …  No delegate will be able to dig into all of the topics, and we need a mix of focus areas. But not being involved and just sticking with the 4 points mentioned here will most probably not work (even if we would have working groups to cover all of this).

I agree this is slightly off-topic but it is an important discussion and SourceCred is part of it. My thoughts on this are the following:   I think it is problematic for Maker if our polls and execs are such that the amount of effort required to vote in an informed manner is equivalent to a near full-time job. This would mean that the only people who can understand and vote on different issues are those delegates who treat delegation as a full-time job. The ordinary MKR holder is simply overwhelmed with information and cannot keep up with the protocol developments. If this is the direction we are heading in, then that’s a big red flag for me. Direct democracy (a close analogue of our structure) works reasonably well for entire nation states (for example, in Switzerland) so it should also work for a protocol like ours which has a much narrower range of issues that gets voted on.   I view the basic task of delegation as the following: Vote as an informed MKR holder would + tell people why you voted the way you did. Neither task should require full-time or near full-time amount of work. In some ways, it is probably the way you view RWA (also a domain I am unfamiliar with).   I think that delegates will find/have already found areas within Maker that they are passionate about and will develop expertise and contribute substantially there. If and when they do, that effort should be 100% compensated. The mechanism for it should be no different to the community member who makes a similar contribution e.g. via a CU, via a grant like that for makerburn and so on. Your MOMC work and Paper’s offboarding structure work fall under this category for me.   You may be correct that we don’t have the right mechanism for such contributions and many are going unrewarded. And with SourceCred going away for such contributors, it feels even worse. My quibble here is that by bringing it under the umbrella of delegate compensation and suggesting that it is insufficient, we are mixing the two issues.

AstronautThis:  I think it is problematic for Maker if our polls and execs are such that the amount of effort required to vote in an informed manner is equivalent to a near full-time job. This would mean that the only people who can understand and vote on different issues are those delegates who treat delegation as a full-time job. The ordinary MKR holder is simply overwhelmed with information and cannot keep up with the protocol developments. If this is the direction we are heading in, then that’s a big red flag for me. Direct democracy (a close analogue of our structure) works reasonably well for entire nation states (for example, in Switzerland) so it should also work for a protocol like ours which has a much narrower range of issues that gets voted on.   Totally agree. But let’s have a look at what has happened with all the Rate-Changes Polls (few remember those funny -2%, 1%, -0.5%, -0.25%, 0%, +0.25%, +0.5%, +1%, +2% onchain polls) that got replaced by the Rate Setting Framework which then got replaced by PPGs like MOMC. I tend to say the evolution of “too complex to understand” to “reasonable” has been made here. We need to do a lot more of those things, to make it easier for non-fulltime-observers to participate in the governance process.     AstronautThis:  I view the basic task of delegation as the following: Vote as an informed MKR holder would + tell people why you voted the way you did. Neither task should require full-time or near full-time amount of work. In some ways, it is probably the way you view RWA (also a domain I am unfamiliar with).   yes, but this only works if you have a fellow delegate (or other expert) that you can rely on. if nobody is an expert on anything, this will get complicated and can only be done if we have PPG-like structures (call them workinggroups) for all topics relevant for governance.     AstronautThis:  I think that delegates will find/have already found areas within Maker that they are passionate about and will develop expertise and contribute substantially there. If and when they do, that effort should be 100% compensated. The mechanism for it should be no different to the community member who makes a similar contribution e.g. via a CU, via a grant like that for makerburn and so on. Your MOMC work and Paper’s offboarding structure work fall under this category for me.   agree, but if we remove sourcecred from this mechanism the only way to get directly compensated is by joining a CU or going for a grant.

AstronautThis:  My quibble here is that by bringing it under the umbrella of delegate compensation and suggesting that it is insufficient, we are mixing the two issues.   For sure, these are separate subjects and should not be interwoven. I believe some might have a “quibble” with what improvements GovAlpha is going to Add to the current Governance mining program, as oppose to subtracting? And how will GovAlpha create governance network effects? I think these are some of the “quibbles” that need to be ratified before we debate if we should nickel-and-dime  the community to death. Just my two quid.

SourceCred definitely works to pique one’s interest in involvement (based on my sample size of 1).  Perhaps the bigger issue lies in publicizing it’s existence?  Maybe I was missing something but I’ve been reading these forums on and off for a few months (not always signed in) and this is the first time I’ve heard of this program.  Is it possible to notify all new users who get to trust level 1?  Or perhaps this is by design and you want it to take some work to opt in?  I’m just thinking that I most certainly would have opted in and spent more time here had I known earlier.

SourceCred should be available to everyone, anyone and maintained/rewarded strictly as the algorithm works to reward engagement on the Forum. Every participant and potential participant should be so incentivized to be as knowledgeable as possible about as many discussions/topics as possible. Even if a person spent every waking hour devoted to MakerDAO, there’s more going on here than any human can keep up with while also bringing valuable, informed contributions to the table.  Having SourceCred rewards signals that we value the effort everyone is making and hopefully the extra DAI correlated with that effort, makes it more fun and satisfying to engage in the activity. The amount of payment itself surely isn’t the sole or even in my case a significant factor. The program expresses appreciation which is otherwise hard to feel from a decentralized group. It says, hey - we see you and your efforts here. Thank you! There’s a psychological component here I haven’t seen mentioned.

This is definitely a tangent from SourceCred, but I want to weigh in,     AstronautThis:  I think it is problematic for Maker if our polls and execs are such that the amount of effort required to vote in an informed manner is equivalent to a near full-time job.   Why? I’m not saying that Maker should be as esoteric and inscrutable as possible, but people who lead organizations generally don’t do it part-time.     AstronautThis:  If this is the direction we are heading in, then that’s a big red flag for me.   Why? I think I generally disagree with your whole post.     AstronautThis:  Direct democracy (a close analogue of our structure) works reasonably well for entire nation states (for example, in Switzerland)   There are very few direct democracies and they have well documented weaknesses, namely that voters are often not well enough informed. I’d much rather orient our governance aspirations toward deliberative opinion polling.     AstronautThis:  You may be correct that we don’t have the right mechanism for such contributions and many are going unrewarded.   I’m in favor of exploring more mechanisms to reward contributors, but I don’t think we should aspire to have 10s of mechanism. It’s hard enough to design a single mechanism that is hard to game. At some point, to becomes micromanagement and you get better results by just trusting people.

PaperImperium:  Not to be pessimistic, but this has been the case the entire time I’ve been exposed to Maker. Or that’s my personal, totally-not-based-on-anything-but-anecdote. Does anyone feel differently?   Completely my impression as well for the past few years.   The amount of material, posts, etc to review is growing by some power law (which isn’t even remotely linear at this point which would be bad enough on its own). Number of CUs increasing at what 1-2/Q or more.  RWA itself is one complicated beast that I don’t think any one single person has enough expertise to handle (this requires a team of multiple experts and eyes). I would hazard the delegates as a team simply don’t have the required time/expertise to manage this. SourceCred is interesting and a good way to involve people that, when compared to delegate compensation actually is cheap IMO. I have from last GovAlpha financial report SourceCred expenses 25K/month.   This is for all contributors - across the board.    We can look at where the DAI is going and make some adjustments I think given the total amount of contributions (in terms of actual man hours) what we pay is cheap for what we get honestly. Even @s_ben has been adamant that communities should continuously adapt their rewards to fit their goals because stagnant SC instances over time end up being farmed/gamed/mined.   The Maker community via forums and chat/discord I have generally found to be of the highest quality of ALL of the DAOs I participate in.     AstronautThis:  It has always been the case that some delegates do work that goes above and beyond their role as a delegate. For example, your work with MOMC, starting various signal requests, etc. has nothing to do with being a delegate and should therefore be compensated independently on top of whatever delegate compensation model we have.   I think this is a difficult distinction and a general problem with respect to quantifying work effort against quality or value of work.   There is a general tendency at EVERY DAO, and community I have worked with to basically take what they can for free, and pay the least for what they need. I think we should stick to the topic at hand and think about how SourceCred could be a bonus to all of the people being paid at Maker (having one SC instance we fund for bonuses for people who are already paid) and another just for people who are NOT being paid.   Though honestly we are distinctly back to the sybil problem here.   I know a number of people who have multiple handles in the forums so we are back to deciding how much to pay for what. Given forums are one of many important social communication mechanisms for everyone I think we need to have a reward component for ALL paid Maker players - as a bonus and one for everyone else.   Fortunately it isn’t hard to have two SC components running and adjusting funding.

psychonaut:  Why? I think I generally disagree with your whole post.     Do you agree that delegation is not a full-time role nor anywhere near that? Because currently, most of our delegates have a full-time job that’s unrelated to Maker. And this is the right setup in my opinion and it should stay this way.   With respect to @PaperImperium and @MakerMan’s posts above, I disagree that Maker has become so inscrutable that it is impossible to be an informed voter without spending several hours a day on Maker related items. Is it easy to be an informed voter? No, it takes some effort. Is it as hard as being suggested here? Also no, and evidence of this beyond my anecdotal experience is that delegates hold full-time non-Maker roles.   The first step of governance is to have signal requests on the forum. These run on the premise that a forum participant is presented with the governance problem, able to understand the issue via a forum discussion and vote on it. If many delegates feel that this is not doable without extensive research, then I think I am not the only one who would disagree. On-chain votes is just an extension of this process. My thoughts on delegates taking on additional roles of becoming subject matter experts and recommending policy directions is in my previous posts. But I view this is an “above and beyond” activity and more importantly, one that is not exclusive to delegates. Happy to discuss this issue in a separate thread to see how the community expects governance participation to work in the near to mid-term future.

I did like that little trickle every so often… Do we pay out substantial sums to people already getting paid? I’ve only ever gotten enough to cover some failed txs  Maybe I haven’t been on the forums enough though!

AstronautThis:  And this is the right setup in my opinion and it should stay this way.   It seems like you regard the current situation with Recognized Delegates as if the Maker ecosystem has achieved its goals and there is no scope for change or improvement. Okay, your view probably isn’t that one-sided, but let’s assume it is just for the sake of discussion.      AstronautThis:  most of our delegates have a full-time job that’s unrelated to Maker   This would be expected given that the delegate compensation program is still in a trial phase, not even ratified as a MIP. In addition, it is not clear to me what the appropriate level of compensation is. I’m not sure whether we are compensating delegates enough to face the prospect of MKR holders undelegating from them. The job is practically never secure. It would be prudent to keep a backup job around, at least at the current compensation level.     AstronautThis:  My thoughts on delegates taking on additional roles of becoming subject matter experts and recommending policy directions is in my previous posts.   I don’t know whether most MKR holders share your views on this. I expect that there is a constant pressure for Recognized Delegates to come up with creative and compelling reasons to attract MKR interest. My sense is that we’re just getting started as a DAO and that we’ll see a lot of novel and surprising ideas tried out in the future.

MakerMan:  Number of CUs increasing at what 1-2/Q or more. RWA itself is one complicated beast that I don’t think any one single person has enough expertise to handle (this requires a team of multiple experts and eyes). I would hazard the delegates as a team simply don’t have the required time/expertise to manage this.   This is compounded by the fact that a significant proportion of contributors are non-native or advanced English speakers, which for many requires a significant extra effort to communicate at an appropriate level.   Add to this the fact that many of us have no experience in finance, IT or blockchain technology. We also have huge differences in culture, living standards and education and communication, which can also lead to misunderstandings. So after a hard day, this is where we need to pick up the thread.  I think this is another reason why more and more people may fall behind in the future.

I support @AstronautThis 's line of thinking here. In my brief time as a Delegate (6 weeks) I can see great value in Recognized Delegates over time developing areas of focus or specialty within the DAO. One could easily work the equivalent of full-time job on any number of proposals and initiatives currently underway. Since 100% voting participation is the goal, a divide and conquer approach to Delegate Voting would mean as a group we develop complementary areas of expertise. Each RD can then somewhat rely on the deeper work other Recognized Delegates are doing to understand and contribute to specific work streams. This coordinated approach would help inform voting decisions where a particular RD does not have the expertise or cannot dedicate time to be appropriately and expertly informed. I also support the notion that having Recognized Delegates who are active in other communities and doing other work in the Real World is enormously valuable to the DAO.

ultraschuppi:  I am not considering quitting my offchain job for 12k/month, additional 1k-2k/month more is not going to make a huge difference on my decision       ultraschuppi:  Compensation for Recognized Delegates is not enough to go all-in (and solo!) right now   This surprised me. purrfection:  This surprised me. At $12,000/month, we’re talking about a $144,000+ salary for part-time job!   I believe it’s more about Job Security — as I am sure you’re aware— there’s ZERO job security/guarantee for Delegates—on any given day—a delegate can be booted into the street (for lack of a better description). And as You know, the well-being of the Family matters more than anything in the world. I don’t think any of us can deny that. I think it’s best for the community to focus on how we can improve and scale the Governance Mining network effects of SourceCred, as oppose to debate this, that, and that. I believe that’s a zero-sum game—waste of time and energy. Looking forward to hearing from @GovAlpha-Core-Unit and their proposal for a brand new Governance Mining initiative.

I think the discussion is going in a wrong direction and specifically attacking the Recognized Delegates on how much they get is not cool. This is about SC. That people can earn a lot of money with the DAO I see more as a success, there is a big incentive to also participate in the DAO. This will in the long run increase the quality in all areas. I mean the Recognized Delegates like @ultraschuppi bring a big value to the DAO, also it gives me the incentive to improve the quality of my contributions. This is all about the SC it should increase the qualitative activity in the forum, ultimately so that the DAO benefits from it. If you have people who perform extremely well, with their experience and knowledge, it can be a great incentive for new people to contribute their ideas and work because they are rewarded with quality and become better, and as a measure of quality the SC is actually quite good, I think if it attracts more people this effect will be even clearer. I am also looking forward to read the proposal from Gov Alpha.

You’re right that this has derailed in this thread, let’s stop it. I’ve thought a lot about whether I should even write this because no matter how politely I bring it up, it can cause negative emotions. It wasn’t my intention to criticize anyone. I was simply surprised that the delegates are still not focusing full time on the DAO. If I understood well the discussion around this, that was the point, Sourcecred alone was not enough to get someone to participate full time. I thought that was resolved, so I missed it at some point. Unfortunately job security is indeed bad, but the skills learned here result in highly marketable knowledge. The trade-off between risk and reward must be made here too, and it is up to each individual to decide whether to take the risk.  I think the risk premium is already included in this salary with other incentives, but if not, it can be adjusted.     makercaesar:  I think the discussion is going in a wrong direction and specifically attacking the Recognized Delegates on how much they get is not cool.   I am sorry if anyone took this as an attack.  However, I think pointing out external facts can colour opinions and I hope this is desirable on this forum.
